messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 55 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Near-Optimal Quantum Coreset Construction Algorithms for Clustering

Paper Abstract: Abstract k𝑘k-Clustering in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d} (e.g., k𝑘k-median and k𝑘k-means) is a fundamental machine learning problem. While near-linear time approximation algorithms were known in the classical setting for a dataset with cardinality n𝑛n, it remains open to find sublinear-time quantum algorithms. We give quantum algorithms that find coresets for k𝑘k-clustering in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d} with O~​(n​k​d3/2)~𝑂𝑛𝑘superscript𝑑32\tilde{O}(\sqrt{nk}d^{3/2}) query complexity. Our coreset reduces the input size from n𝑛n to poly​(k​ε−1​d)poly𝑘superscript𝜀1𝑑\mathrm{poly}(k\varepsilon^{-1}d), so that existing α𝛼\alpha-approximation algorithms for clustering can run on top of it and yield (1+ε)​α1𝜀𝛼(1+\varepsilon)\alpha-approximation. This eventually yields a quadratic speedup for various k𝑘k-clustering approximation algorithms. We complement our algorithm with a nearly matching lower bound, that any quantum algorithm must make Ω​(n​k)Ω𝑛𝑘\Omega(\sqrt{nk}) queries in order to achieve even O​(1)𝑂1O(1)-approximation for k𝑘k-clustering.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 55 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 55"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Read the fine print.",
        "Exact and approximation algorithms for clustering.",
        "Quantum clustering algorithms.",
        "Quantum speedup for graph sparsification, cut approximation and Laplacian solving.",
        "Distributed k-means and k-median clustering on general communication topologies.",
        "Quantum lower bounds by polynomials.",
        "Quantum machine learning.",
        "Quantum amplitude amplification and estimation.",
        "Clustering high dimensional dynamic data streams.",
        "Coresets for clustering in excluded-minor graphs and beyond.",
        "The power of uniform sampling for coresets.",
        "Polylogarithmic sketches for clustering.",
        "Sampling-based sublinear low-rank matrix arithmetic framework for dequantizing quantum machine learning.",
        "Fair clustering through fairlets.",
        "On the fixed-parameter tractability of capacitated clustering.",
        "Near-linear time approximation schemes for clustering in doubling metrics.",
        "A new coreset framework for clustering.",
        "Towards optimal lower bounds for k-median and k-means coresets.",
        "Machine learning & artificial intelligence in the quantum domain: a review of recent progress.",
        "Classification with quantum neural networks on near term processors.",
        "A unified framework for approximating and clustering data.",
        "Quantum random access memory.",
        "A fast quantum mechanical algorithm for database search.",
        "Bounded geometries, fractals, and low-distortion embeddings.",
        "Preparing many copies of a quantum state in the black-box model.",
        "On coresets for k-means and k-median clustering.",
        "Supervised learning with quantum-enhanced feature spaces.",
        "Fully-dynamic coresets.",
        "Negative weights make adversaries stronger.",
        "Coresets for clustering in Euclidean spaces: importance sampling is nearly optimal.",
        "Approximate nearest neighbors: towards removing the curse of dimensionality.",
        "Extensions of Lipschitz mappings into a Hilbert space.",
        "Quantum perceptron models.",
        "Quantum spectral clustering.",
        "Quantum classification of the MNIST dataset via slow feature analysis.",
        "q-means: A quantum algorithm for unsupervised machine learning.",
        "Quantum adversary (upper) bound.",
        "Quantum query complexity of state conversion.",
        "Sublinear quantum algorithms for training linear and kernel-based classifiers.",
        "Sublinear classical and quantum algorithms for general matrix games.",
        "Quantum algorithms for supervised and unsupervised machine learning.",
        "On the complexity of some common geometric location problems.",
        "Optimal time bounds for approximate clustering.",
        "The quantum query complexity of approximating the median and related statistics.",
        "Unsupervised machine learning on a hybrid quantum computer.",
        "Quantum clustering with k-means: a hybrid approach.",
        "Quantum support vector machine for big data classification.",
        "Span programs are equivalent to quantum query algorithms.",
        "Supervised learning with quantum computers, volume 17.",
        "Implementing a distance-based classifier with a quantum interference circuit.",
        "Improved coresets for Euclidean k-means.",
        "Strong coresets for k-median and subspace approximation: Goodbye dimension.",
        "Quick k-median, k-center, and facility location for sparse graphs.",
        "Quantum probability oracles & multidimensional amplitude estimation.",
        "Quantum algorithms for nearest-neighbor methods for supervised and unsupervised learning."
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 55 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Near-Optimal Quantum Coreset Construction Algorithms for Clustering, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
